> Love the book, looking forward to the movie. Though, I do think Matt Damon wasn't the greatest to cast as Watney. I would think someone like Robert Downey Jr. could nail Watney's unique brand of humor alot better than Damon.

When I read the book I had him pictured kinda like Kurt Russel in "Big Trouble in Little China" as Jack Burton, (only six tons smarter than Burton of course) however I've got to admit that Downy would have been a great choice, The style of humor he portrayed as Tony Stark/Iron Man is right up Watney's isle.
I pictured him younger, more of a post-doc age, making his love of disco even more odd.

> 
> Love the book, looking forward to the movie. Though, I do think Matt Damon wasn't the greatest to cast as Watney. I would think someone like Robert Downey Jr. could nail Watney's unique brand of humor alot better than Damon.

There is a certain meta humour in there if they use Robert and include the scene in the book where Watney was suggesting he could puncture the palms of his suit to fly himself to rescue, remarking it would be like "Iron man"

> 
> I pictured him younger, more of a post-doc age, making his love of disco even more odd.

I am pretty sure Watney *hates* disco. It was the only kind of music he has on hand and he has to listen to it all the time if he want any music at all.

> 
> I pictured him younger, more of a post-doc age, making his love of disco even more odd.

I distinctly remember his reaction to finding disco music in the commander's personals as being something along the lines of "Damn it Lewis!"... he didn't sound too pleased ![;)](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_wink.gif)

I think Matt Damon is a fine choice for the role. You really don't want somebody who would be typecast or it'll distract the audience.

I also think the portrayal of NASA staff looks good. It isn't the same environment as it was back in the '60s.

Best,

-Slashy

Forums are meant for discussion aren't they?

> 
> Not saying I'm not going to enjoy it! (sorry if it came off that way) I'm super excited for it, and it looks really good from what I've seen so far. I'm just interested in seeing what it's going to be like and what I can predict is going to happen.

I think that its a trailer and we need to see what happens. I edit video and mix sound for a living and I can tell you right off the bat you can hear many abrupt sound cutouts and splices to tell a story in a trailer that is compelling for the audience. There is an abrupt cut at 1:53 that seems to be causing everyone to go crazy. They mixed Jessica Chastain and Kate Maras lines together to make it sound like one person was saying it. Then they combined it with a message popping up on a screen and then showed mara and chastain looking at a screen. We don't know what screen they are looking at and we don't know what screen the message popped up on. Its all cut together to make it look like they are receiving a message from Watney. I know in my bones that they are going to stick to the original plot and not tell the crew. Because then why even have Rich Purnell? Why have someone like Sean Bean play a character like Mitch if you aren't gonna setup for some emotional moments that need to be delivered by an amazing actor. Those characters are vital to that plot. I know this thread is for discussion that is why I made it. Please carry on and you absolutely don't have to agree with me or each other. But remember its just a trailer to wet your palate and to make people who haven't read the book want to see the movie.

Amazing read! Pretty much polished it off in four sittings which, for me, is a miracle (I'm a slow reader when it comes to fiction).

Regarding the film version... I have some hope that it will make the transition successfully. I felt the novel was almost written in a screenplay style. As I was reading it, I could easily imagine how any future film could rearrange sections to make a coherent film.

As long as they don't fall into the trap of making Venk the bureaucratic bad guy (akin to the flight surgeon in Apollo 13), I'm sure Ridley Scott will navigate this production like a Martinez landing.

Oh, and Matt Damon is a great choice for the role.

I am in email contact with Andy Weir, I asked him a few questions about his book and here's what he said.

> 
> The crew transport to and from Hermes is done while Hermes is in Low 
> Earth Orbit. So it's done in under a day. I imagine something like an 
> 
> Orion mission or maybe even commercial LEO delivery through something 
> 
> like SpaceX.
> 
> The rovers aren't based on any existing real-world design. Though 
> 
> they're very similar to the current NASA prototype. However, the ones in 
> 
> the book are larger. They don't have a built-in toilet. Instead the 
> 
> astronauts are expected to use waste bags.
> 
> I didn't define what the boosters were nor their total delta-v. Though 
> 
> the ULA booster that carried the (failed) Iris probe was originally the 
> 
> booster intended for a Saturn probe. So whatever delta-V is needed for a 
> 
> Saturn transfer and orbital insertion. As for the Chinese booster, it 
> 
> was designed to put a very heavy payload into solar orbit between 
> 
> Mercury and Venus. That means the orbital velocity would be very high, 
> 
> and with a very heavy payload that means lots of power.
